examples.query: pubdate:[2014-01 TO 2014-12] author:("Finkbeiner, D. P.") doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language only specifies last name "Finkbeiner", but query fabricates initials "D. P." in author field.
The term quasar is unnecessarily quoted; it is a single word and does not require quotes.
Second-order operator syntax is malformed: references() must wrap the inner query in parentheses.
Natural language asks for papers referenced by quasar research; using abs:quasar is acceptable, but quoting suggests an exact phrase not requested.

examples.nl: "Who's Who Among Black Americans" biographical directory
examples.query: title:(Who's OR Who OR Among OR Black OR Americans)

issues.description: Unbalanced quotes due to the apostrophe in Who's being treated as a quote character; query is not syntactically valid as written.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("Who's" OR Who OR Among OR Black OR Americans)

issues.description: OR-ing every token from the title is overly permissive and will match many unrelated records; it teaches a bad habit for title searches.
Natural language requests a specific titled directory; the query should target the exact title rather than individual words.
Missing boolean operator between the year clause group and doctype filter; query as written is not valid ADS syntax.
Author name formatting is inconsistent with standard ADS quoting/spacing; should include a space after the comma for clarity and typical ADS style.

examples.nl: "Bean's History and Directory of Nevada County" historical documentation
examples.query: title:(Bean's OR History OR Directory OR Nevada OR County)

issues.description: Unbalanced quotes due to the apostrophe in Bean's; ADS quoting uses double quotes, and the single quote here breaks parsing.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("Bean's" OR History OR Directory OR Nevada OR County)

issues.description: NL appears to reference a specific title; the query explodes it into individual OR terms, which is a poor habit for title lookups and will retrieve many unrelated records.
issues.suggested_fix: title:"Bean's History and Directory of Nevada County"

issues.description: NL includes 'historical documentation' but the query does not reflect that concept (and ADS is not primarily for historical documentation outside scholarly records).
Natural language specifies only last name ("George Smoot" implies full name, but query uses fabricated initial format "Smoot, G." rather than matching the provided full name).

examples.nl: papers by Bao, Zhenan on organic electronics

issues.description: Query has unbalanced/malformed quotes and punctuation: abs:"author", Zhenan"" is not valid ADS syntax.
The query includes abs:"author" which is unrelated to the natural language request and appears to be an accidental token.
Topic is expressed as a single quoted phrase; for topic searches, prefer boolean keywords unless an exact phrase was explicitly requested.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Bao, Zhenan" abs:(organic AND electronics) doctype:article

issues.description: Query uses first-author constraint (^author) but the natural language input does not specify 'first author' or equivalent.
Invalid author field syntax: author:^hamuy should be written as ^author:"Hamuy" or author:"^Hamuy" (and author names should be quoted/cased as names).
Category is 'first_author' but the NL input does not request first-author; category should reflect an author+year query instead.

examples.nl: papers by feinstein as first author

issues.description: Natural language only specifies last name 'feinstein', but query fabricates full given name 'adina'.
First-author constraint is expressed correctly, but uses a nonstandard placement of ^ inside quotes; prefer ^author:"Last" for clarity/consistency.
Category 'first_author' is acceptable but could be more descriptive (e.g., 'author_first').
Natural language only specifies last name "cheung" but query fabricates an initial ("m").
Category is first_author and query uses first-author syntax, but NL does not explicitly request first/lead author.
Single-word topic term does not need quotes in abs:.
NL includes topic "stellar flares" but query only includes "flare" (singular) and omits "stellar"; should reflect both concepts.

examples.nl: papers by kovacs on supernova randomness

issues.description: NL specifies only last name "kovacs" but query fabricates an initial ("kovacs, e").
Topic terms are placed in title: fields, which is overly restrictive and not implied by NL; NL asks about the topic, not necessarily words in the title.
Malformed author field quoting/structure: `author:"^Finkelstein," S.` has an unmatched quote and places `S.` outside the quoted author string, making the query invalid.
Fabricated/unsupported author initial: NL says "Finkelstein S" (ambiguous), but query uses `S.` as if it were a verified initial and also implies a comma-formatted name without clear support.
NL does not explicitly request first author, but query uses first-author syntax (`^`).

examples.nl: Where to educate 1898 1899 guide best private schools higher institutions learning United States
examples.query: title:(Where OR educate, OR 1898–1899. OR guide OR best)

issues.description: Invalid title field syntax: uses parentheses with OR terms and includes punctuation/commas inside tokens (e.g., 'educate,' '1898–1899.') which is not valid ADS query tokenization for fielded search.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Where OR educate OR "1898 1899" OR guide OR best)

issues.description: Natural language describes a guide about private schools/higher institutions/learning in the United States (topic/title-like), but the query only includes a few generic words and omits key concepts like private schools, higher institutions, learning, and United States.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("private schools" AND ("higher institutions" OR colleges OR universities) AND "United States" AND guide AND (1898 OR 1899))

issues.description: Using OR across generic terms ('Where OR educate OR guide OR best') is overly permissive and will retrieve many irrelevant records; for a specific guide/title-like request, terms should be combined with AND and/or phrased.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(guide AND "private schools" AND "United States" AND (1898 OR 1899))

issues.description: Category 'content' is too vague; this is specifically a title search example.

First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^monnier") is not a valid way to indicate first author. The caret should be applied to the field (e.g., ^author:"Monnier") or inside the quoted author string (author:"^Monnier").
author:("^monnier") uses unnecessary parentheses and an unusual quoted token; while it may parse, it is nonstandard and risks teaching malformed author syntax.

examples.nl: "Hunting Trails on Three Continents" Boone and Crockett Club book
examples.query: title:(Hunting OR Trails OR Three OR Continents; OR Book)

issues.description: Malformed query syntax: semicolon inside parentheses (`Continents;`) is not valid ADS boolean syntax and will likely break parsing.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Hunting AND Trails AND Three AND Continents) doctype:book

issues.description: Using OR between individual title words is overly permissive and will return many unrelated records; title searches should typically require all key words (AND) or use an exact phrase if explicitly requested.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Hunting AND Trails AND Continents) doctype:book

issues.description: NL specifies a book (Boone and Crockett Club book) but query does not constrain document type and adds an unrelated token `Book` inside the title field.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Hunting AND Trails AND Three AND Continents) doctype:book

issues.description: The token `Book` is placed inside `title:` rather than using `doctype:book`; this teaches incorrect field usage for document type constraints.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Hunting AND Trails AND Three AND Continents) doctype:book

issues.description: Category labeled as `content` is vague/misleading for a title+doctype lookup; a more appropriate category would be `title` or `publication_type`.
Query uses '^carnall' without a valid field prefix; first-author syntax must be applied to the author: field (e.g., ^author:"...").
NL does not specify 'first author', but query implies first-author constraint via '^'.
NL requests papers by an author; query should explicitly use author: field rather than an unfielded token.
Author value is malformed: uses a comma inside quotes without a space and includes a caret inside the quoted string (author:"^fong,w"), which is not a valid author-name format per the reference.
Natural language says "papers by fong w" (not explicitly "first author"), but the query forces first-author-only with ^.

examples.nl: papers by Robinett in Astronomy and Astrophysics 2022

issues.description: Query does not reflect the natural language request: it uses abs: with a bibcode-like token instead of author/journal/year constraints. NL asks for papers by Robinett in Astronomy & Astrophysics in 2022.
The query appears to be a bibcode lookup embedded in abs:, which is retrieval rather than NL-to-query translation and teaches a bad habit.
Using abs: to search for a bibcode-like identifier is incorrect field usage; identifiers should use bibcode: or identifier:, and topic searches should use abs: with keywords.
Category labeled as 'topic' is misleading; this is primarily an author/publication/year filter query.
Natural language only specifies last name "arevalo" but query fabricates the initial "p" in author:"arevalo, p".
Natural language includes the topic/term "astronomy" but the query uses it only as a collection filter; it does not search for the concept "astronomy" in content fields.

examples.nl: L/T transition brown dwarfs atmospheric properties

issues.description: Query uses an exact title-like phrase in abs: ("The L/T Transition") instead of topic keywords from the natural language input.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:("L/T transition" AND "brown dwarfs" AND atmospheric AND properties)

issues.description: Over-quoting a multi-word topic phrase; NL did not request an exact phrase search.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:("L/T transition" AND "brown dwarfs" AND atmospheric AND properties)

issues.description: Query omits key concepts from NL input (brown dwarfs, atmospheric properties) and adds a leading article 'The' not present in NL.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:("L/T transition" AND "brown dwarfs" AND atmospheric AND properties)

issues.description: Uses invalid field name `bibgroup:`; valid field is `bibgroup:` without quotes only if needed, but the value must be an enumerated bibgroup and SETI is not a valid bibgroup in the provided list.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(narrowband AND radio AND SETI AND technosignatures)

issues.description: Query adds a bibgroup constraint not explicitly requested in the natural language input (NL mentions SETI as a topic, not a curated bibgroup filter).
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(narrowband AND radio AND SETI AND technosignatures)

issues.description: Bibgroup value `SETI` is not in the valid bibgroup list; using it would teach invalid enumerated values.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(narrowband AND radio AND SETI AND technosignatures)

issues.description: Category `compound` is not a clear/standard category label (e.g., topic, author, operator).

examples.nl: papers by natascha forster on cosmic noon

issues.description: NL requests papers by an author (natascha forster), but the query does not use the author: field and instead mixes the name into abs:, which will not reliably retrieve papers by that author.
abs:(cosmic noon natascha) uses implicit OR/loose tokenization inside parentheses; for topic terms it should require both words in 'cosmic noon' (phrase or AND).

examples.nl: papers about lurkers in SETI research

issues.description: Query uses an invalid field prefix: \bibgroup:. Valid field is bibgroup: (no backslash).
NL requests 'papers', which should map to doctype:article; query includes it, so no issue here.
Query is unfielded 'lurker' and does not include SETI as a topic term; bibgroup:SETI alone may not capture 'SETI research' as a topic constraint.
Category 'compound' is vague; more descriptive category like 'topic+filter' would be better.

examples.nl: papers by poletto on solar corona

issues.description: Query does not use the author field for an author-constrained request; it incorrectly places the author name in abs: and omits the topic constraint (solar corona).
Fabricated author initial 'g.'; NL only specifies last name 'poletto'.
NL says 'papers', so doctype:article should be included (it is included, but current query is otherwise mis-specified).

examples.nl: 2017 Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics Naab

issues.description: Generated query is an identifier/bibcode-style lookup rather than a natural-language-to-query translation; training on this teaches retrieval-by-identifier instead of query construction.
NL mentions a specific venue/year/author name, but the query collapses everything into a single identifier string, losing the explicit constraints and not demonstrating proper fielded translation.
issues.suggested_fix: pub:"Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics" year:2017 author:"Naab"

issues.description: Query contains malformed author clause: author:"^bolin," has an unmatched quote/comma and stray token b, making the query invalid.
Natural language requests papers by Bolin on asteroids; query does not include an asteroids topic constraint (and includes an extraneous token).
Query forces first-author (^), but NL only says 'papers by bolin' (not 'first author').

examples.nl: papers citing "A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies"
examples.query: abs: HI citations(title:A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies) doctype:article

issues.description: Second-order operator usage is malformed: citations() must wrap a complete inner query; current query mixes an extra abs:HI term outside the operator and lacks quoting for the multi-word title inside title:.
issues.suggested_fix: citations(title:"A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies") doctype:article

issues.description: NL asks for papers citing a specific paper title; adding abs:HI is an extra topical constraint not requested and will incorrectly filter results.
issues.suggested_fix: citations(title:"A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies") doctype:article

issues.description: Multi-word value in title: should be quoted; otherwise parsing may be incorrect or overly broad.
issues.suggested_fix: citations(title:"A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies") doctype:article

issues.description: First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^calamida") is not a valid way to indicate first author. Use ^author:"Calamida" or author:"^Calamida".
Unnecessary parentheses around a single quoted term in author:("^calamida"); while it may parse, it is nonstandard and can teach bad habits.
Author name case should be normalized (Calamida) for consistency with typical ADS query examples; NL provides 'Calamida' capitalized.
NL requests papers by the author 'Ould-Boukatinne', but the query splits the surname into author:"Ould" and abs:"-Boukatinne", incorrectly treating part of the name as a topic term.
abs:"-Boukatinne" is an invalid/ill-formed way to represent a hyphenated surname; it introduces a leading '-' inside a quoted phrase and misuses abs: for an author constraint.
Category is labeled 'topic' but the NL input is an author search.

examples.nl: papers by adams and shu from 1986
examples.query: pubdate:[1986-01 TO 1986-12] author:("adams, f." "shu, f.") doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language input gives last names only ('adams' and 'shu'), but the query fabricates initials ('adams, f.' and 'shu, f.').
Invalid author field syntax: author:"^parise." includes a trailing period inside the quoted name, which is not supported/standard and will likely reduce recall or mis-parse the author token.
Natural language does not specify first author, but query enforces first-author-only via ^.
Category 'first_author' does not match the natural language input (no first-author intent stated).

examples.nl: papers by Foreman-Mackey on MCMC sampling

issues.description: Author name is incorrectly split: author:"Foreman" and abs:"-Mackey" does not represent the author Foreman-Mackey and incorrectly treats part of the surname as a topic term.
Topic phrase is not represented; if added, it should not be a single quoted multi-word phrase unless explicitly requested as an exact phrase.
First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^rawlings") is not a valid way to indicate first author. Should use ^author:"rawlings" or author:"^rawlings".
Unnecessary parentheses around a single quoted term in author: field; may confuse training and is non-idiomatic.

examples.nl: papers by zeng li first author

issues.description: First-author syntax is incorrect: the caret (^) must apply to the author field, not be placed inside the quoted author string.

NL input only provides last name plus a standalone initial ('ginzburg s') and does not justify fabricating punctuation/case or adding a period; also the query uses 's.' which may be treated as an invented initial formatting rather than literal input.
Category is 'first_author' but NL does not explicitly request first/lead author; adding ^ may mis-train the model to assume first-author intent.
Query adds a first-author constraint not stated in NL.

Natural language specifies only last name ("Roger Penrose" implies full name, but query uses initial "R." which is not explicitly requested as an initial format; however it is derived from the provided first name. Training data should avoid converting full first names into initials unless explicitly given as an initial.

examples.nl: papers by Hill T and Burton from 2005

issues.description: Invalid author clause syntax: author:("^hill,t" "burton") lacks a boolean operator between terms; ADS expects explicit AND/OR or separate author: clauses.
issues.suggested_fix: pubdate:[2005-01 TO 2005-12] author:"^Hill" AND author:"Burton" doctype:article

issues.description: Fabricated author initial for Hill: NL says "Hill T" but query uses "^hill,t" (interpretable as last name Hill with first initial t, but also incorrectly formatted). Burton has no initial in NL, so should not add one.
issues.suggested_fix: pubdate:[2005-01 TO 2005-12] author:"Hill, T" AND author:"Burton" doctype:article

issues.description: Category is first_author, but NL does not specify first/lead author; query also applies first-author marker (^) to Hill without NL justification.
issues.suggested_fix: pubdate:[2005-01 TO 2005-12] author:"Hill, T" AND author:"Burton" doctype:article

issues.description: NL implies two authors (Hill T and Burton) but query structure is ambiguous and may not require both authors due to malformed grouping; should explicitly require both with AND.
issues.suggested_fix: pubdate:[2005-01 TO 2005-12] author:"Hill, T" AND author:"Burton" doctype:article

issues.description: Uses invalid proximity operator syntax 'NEAR5' inside abs:(). ADS proximity syntax is not defined in the provided reference; this will teach unsupported operator usage.

examples.nl: papers by J Young first author

issues.description: Natural language only specifies last name 'Young' (and initial 'J' without a period), but the query uses a fabricated/normalized initial format 'J.' which is not explicitly provided.
First-author constraint is correctly represented, but the caret is embedded inside quotes; prefer the canonical syntax ^author:"Young, J" for clarity/consistency.

examples.nl: papers by K from Soviet Astronomy Letters 1980

issues.description: Query uses abs:(1980SvAL....6..357K), which is effectively a bibcode lookup placed in a content field rather than translating the natural language request.

Natural language requests papers by author 'K' in Soviet Astronomy Letters in 1980, but the query does not use author: or a publication filter (bibstem/pub) and instead targets a single record-like identifier.
Bibcode-like identifier is placed in abs: (content field), which is inappropriate for identifier lookup/constraints.
Category is labeled 'topic' but the intent is primarily author/publication/year filtering.

examples.query: title:(American OR Clipper OR Ships, OR 1833–1858)

issues.description: Uses an invalid field prefix `title:`; valid ADS field is `title:` only if supported, but the provided syntax is malformed with punctuation inside the term list (e.g., `Ships,`). Also includes an en-dash year range token inside title terms rather than using year/year-range fields.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(American AND clipper AND ships) year:1833-1858

issues.description: Uses OR between all tokens, making the query far too permissive (matches any of the words or the years). For a topic-style query, terms should generally be combined with AND unless they are true synonyms.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(American AND clipper AND ships) year:1833-1858

issues.description: Year range is embedded as a title token `1833–1858` instead of using `year:1833-1858` (or pubdate range).
issues.suggested_fix: title:(American AND clipper AND ships) year:1833-1858

issues.description: Contains punctuation inside the boolean list (`Ships,` and `OR 1833–1858`), which is likely unintended and can degrade parsing/precision.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(American AND clipper AND ships) year:1833-1858

issues.description: Category labeled as `content`, but the query is specifically a title+date search; a more specific category like `topic` or `title` (or `content+date`) would be clearer.
Natural language only specifies last name "ibar", but query fabricates an initial ("e").

examples.query: author:("reichart, d") and author:"martin, j" doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language only provides last names ('reichart' and 'martin'), but the query fabricates first initials ('d' and 'j').
Uses nonstandard/possibly invalid author grouping syntax: author:("reichart, d") should be author:"reichart, d" (parentheses are unnecessary and may be misparsed).

examples.query: title:(Granville OR Stuart OR DHS OR Ranch, OR 1879–1887)

issues.description: Uses title: for a non-astronomy/humanities-style query; ADS training data should not include non-scholarly/non-ADS-aligned entities like a ranch name and date span as a title search example.
title:(Granville OR Stuart OR DHS OR Ranch, OR 1879–1887) is overly permissive and also includes a stray comma token 'Ranch,' which will teach bad tokenization habits.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Granville AND Stuart AND DHS AND Ranch) year:1879-1887

issues.description: Uses an en-dash date span token (1879–1887) inside title: instead of a proper year range filter.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Granville AND Stuart AND DHS AND Ranch) year:1879-1887

issues.description: Natural language is primarily a date range plus named entity; the query incorrectly treats the date range as title content and breaks the entity into OR terms, losing the intended constraint.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Granville AND Stuart AND DHS AND Ranch) year:1879-1887

issues.description: First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^Nagao,") is not a valid way to indicate first author; the caret must be applied to the author field or inside the quoted name without extra punctuation.
author:("^Nagao,") uses unnecessary parentheses and includes a trailing comma inside the quoted author string, which can reduce match quality and is nonstandard.
Natural language specifies only last name 'Brunken' but query fabricates initial 's' in author field.
First-author constraint is expressed in a nonstandard/likely incorrect way: author:("^brunken, s"). Preferred syntax is ^author:"Brunken" or author:"^Brunken".

author:("^brunken, s") uses parentheses around a single quoted string; while it may parse, it is unnecessary and risks teaching odd patterns. Also uses lowercase name and includes a comma+initial not supported by NL.
First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^allard") is not a valid way to indicate first author. Should use ^author:"Allard" or author:"^Allard".
Unnecessary parentheses around a single quoted term in author field; may confuse training and is non-idiomatic.
NL says 'allard' (case-insensitive), but query uses lowercase inside quotes; better to preserve canonical capitalization for readability.
Query uses an invalid author syntax '^lambrides' without the required author: field prefix; '^' is only valid with author: (e.g., ^author:"Last" or author:"^Last").
Query implies first-author constraint via '^' but NL only says 'papers by lambrides' (not 'first author').
Natural language specifies only last name "Krełowski" but query fabricates initial "J." in author field.
Author field uses parentheses and quotes in a nonstandard way: author:("Krełowski, J.") is unnecessary and may teach inconsistent formatting.

examples.nl: Povic Marquez Masegosa galaxy classification MNRAS 2015

issues.description: Malformed abs: clause: tokens include trailing commas and an extra boolean operator before a closing parenthesis, making the query invalid.
Natural language includes journal (MNRAS) and year (2015) constraints, but the query omits both.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(galaxy AND classification) author:"Povic" author:"Marquez" author:"Masegosa" bibstem:MNRAS year:2015

issues.description: Author names are placed in abs: (topic field) instead of author:, which misrepresents the user intent and teaches incorrect field usage.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Povic" author:"Marquez" author:"Masegosa" abs:(galaxy AND classification) bibstem:MNRAS year:2015

issues.description: Input implies a search for scholarly papers; adding doctype:article is recommended for training consistency.
issues.suggested_fix: doctype:article author:"Povic" author:"Marquez" author:"Masegosa" abs:(galaxy AND classification) bibstem:MNRAS year:2015

examples.nl: papers by battaglia on galaxy clusters

issues.description: First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^battaglia") is not a valid way to mark first author. Use ^author:"battaglia" or author:"^battaglia".
author:("^battaglia") uses unnecessary parentheses and quoting; while it may parse, it is nonstandard and risks teaching malformed patterns.
Natural language includes the topic 'galaxy clusters' but the query omits any topic constraint (e.g., abs:galaxy abs:clusters).

examples.nl: papers by Pierce, L on stellar evolution

issues.description: Malformed author field quoting/splitting: author:"^Pierce," L. has an unmatched quote and an extraneous token (L.) outside the field, making the query invalid.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"^Pierce, L" abs:(stellar AND evolution) doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language includes the topic 'on stellar evolution' but the query omits any topic constraint.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"^Pierce, L" abs:(stellar AND evolution) doctype:article

issues.description: NL says 'papers' but query should include doctype:article; current query includes it, so no issue here.

examples.nl: papers by Monson in astronomy journals

issues.description: First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^Monson") is not a valid way to indicate first author. Use ^author:"Monson" or author:"^Monson".

NL says "in astronomy journals" but the query uses collection:astronomy, which filters by ADS collection (subject database), not specifically journals. If the intent is refereed journal articles, property:refereed would better match.
Category 'first_author' is plausible, but the NL does not explicitly say 'first author'; it says 'papers by Monson'.

examples.nl: papers by Sajina A first author

issues.description: First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^sajina, A.") is not a valid way to indicate first author. Should use ^author:"..." or author:"^...".
Fabricated author initial/punctuation: NL says 'Sajina A' but query uses 'A.'; also the last name is Sajina, so adding an initial is unnecessary and risks mismatch.
Unnecessary parentheses around a quoted string in author: field; while parentheses can be used for grouping, this form is atypical and may confuse training.
Uses unsupported field/operator `pos(...)`; positional author searching is not part of the provided valid ADS query syntax reference.
Natural language specifies only last name "oort" but query fabricates initial "J" in author:"Oort, J".
Natural language requests author positions 1-3, but the provided syntax reference does not define any valid way to express author position ranges; query cannot be validated/learned from reference.
Category "positional" is not a standard/clear category under the provided reference (no positional operator/field is defined).
Wildcard is placed inside a quoted author phrase; ADS author matching/wildcards should not be embedded this way, and the query likely will not behave as intended.

Natural language input appears to request an author last name plus a first-name/initial prefix; the generated query treats it as a single exact phrase, which can reduce recall and misrepresent the intent.
Category labeled as 'syntax' but the example is primarily an author-field construction/alignment issue.
This is a bibcode lookup (direct identifier retrieval), which should be removed from NL→query translation training data per guidelines.
NL asks to find a specific bibcode; adding doctype:article is an extra constraint not explicitly requested.

examples.nl: weak lensing papers by smith j

issues.description: Natural language specifies author as 'smith j' (initial given), but query uses lowercase initial and may be interpreted as fabricated/incorrect formatting; should preserve explicit initial with proper capitalization.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Smith, J" abs:(weak AND lensing) doctype:article

issues.description: Topic phrase "weak lensing" is quoted without the user requesting an exact phrase; better expressed as boolean topic terms.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Smith, J" abs:(weak AND lensing) doctype:article

examples.nl: papers by Smith, J about infrared astronomy

issues.description: Natural language specifies author as "Smith, J" but the query uses only last name (author:"Smith"), dropping the explicitly provided initial.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Smith, J" abs:(infrared AND astronomy) doctype:article

issues.description: Topic is expressed as a quoted multi-word phrase in abs:, which can teach over-quoting; better to use boolean terms for topics unless an exact phrase was requested.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Smith, J" abs:(infrared AND astronomy) doctype:article

issues.description: NL mentions the author as 'vera rubin' but the query fabricates/normalizes to an initial-only form ("rubin, v") without the full first name explicitly represented; training should avoid introducing initials when not explicitly requested.
The topic phrase "weak lensing" is quoted even though NL did not request an exact phrase; topic terms should generally be combined with boolean operators.
NL includes the full name 'vera rubin' but the query reduces it to an initial form; this can change intent and teaches lossy name handling.

examples.nl: papers by vera rubin on coronal mass ejections since 2018
examples.query: author:"rubin, v" abs:(coronal AND ejections AND mass) year:2018-2023 doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language specifies only last name 'vera rubin' (no initial), but query fabricates initial 'v' in author field.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Rubin" abs:(coronal AND mass AND ejections) year:2018-2023 doctype:article

issues.description: NL says 'since 2018' (open-ended), but query caps the range at 2023, adding an end year not stated.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Rubin" abs:(coronal AND mass AND ejections) year:2018-* doctype:article

examples.nl: dark energy by Oort, J 2018 to 2023

issues.description: Natural language specifies author as "Oort, J" (includes initial), but query uses only last name, losing an explicit constraint.
Topic phrase "dark energy" is quoted; quoting is not necessary unless an exact phrase was explicitly requested.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Oort, J" abs:(dark AND energy) year:2018-2023

issues.description: Category is publication-like, but NL does not explicitly say papers/articles/publications; doctype:article should not be added unless explicitly requested. (No fix needed; just ensure not to add doctype.)

examples.query: author:"oort, j" abs:(coronal AND ejections AND mass) year:2018-2023

issues.description: NL input provides last name only ('oort') but query fabricates first initial ('author:"oort, j"').
issues.suggested_fix: author:"oort" abs:(coronal AND mass AND ejections) year:2018-2023

issues.description: property:software is not a valid property value; 'software' is a valid doctype and also a property, but the NL asks for 'software documentation papers', which aligns better with doctype:software (or possibly doctype:article plus abs:documentation/software if truly papers about software documentation).
Query adds doctype:article, but NL says 'software documentation papers' which is ambiguous; if interpreted as software records, doctype:article is misaligned.
Category 'property' is misleading given the corrected interpretation should primarily use doctype:software (and year).
First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^guptke") is not a valid way to indicate first author. Should use ^author:"guptke" or author:"^guptke".
author:("^guptke") uses unnecessary parentheses and quoting; while not necessarily invalid, it is nonstandard and may not parse as intended for first-author matching.

examples.query: pubdate:[2016-01 TO 2016-12] author:("Piskunov, a. e.") doctype:article

issues.description: NL specifies only last name "Piskunov" but query fabricates initials and full name/format: author:("Piskunov, a. e.").
Author clause uses unnecessary parentheses and quotes around a single author string; also uses lowercase initials with punctuation inside quotes, which is atypical and may reduce match quality.

examples.nl: papers by L on arXiv from 2022

issues.description: Natural language asks for papers by an author with last name 'L' on arXiv from 2022, but the query uses abs: with a bibcode-like token and does not constrain author, arXiv/eprint status, or year.
NL says 'papers' but query uses doctype:article; for 'on arXiv' it should be doctype:eprint (or property:eprint).
Query appears to be attempting a bibcode lookup (2022arXiv220605745L) placed in abs:, which is not a valid NL-to-query topic translation and teaches bad habits.
Category labeled 'topic' but the NL intent is primarily an author + arXiv/year filter (author/filters).
Natural language requests papers by an author, but the query uses abs: (topic/content field) instead of author:.
abs:(napolitano, nicola) uses a comma inside parentheses without quotes; this is non-idiomatic and may parse unexpectedly. For names, use author: with quotes.
Category is labeled 'topic' but the intent is an author search.
First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^Lyra") is not a valid way to indicate first author. Should use ^author:"Lyra" or author:"^Lyra".
Natural language specifies only the last name "Aguilera-Gomez", but the query fabricates the initial "C." in the author field.
Natural language specifies only last name 'Chandrasekhar' but query fabricates the initial 'S.'

examples.nl: papers by Cuk on planetary dynamics

issues.description: Query does not reflect the natural language: it uses an invalid/undefined token `kw4` and does not include the requested topic constraint for planetary dynamics (e.g., abs: terms).
`kw4` is not a valid ADS/SciX field or operator in the provided syntax reference.
Natural language only specifies last name 'Cuk'; query fabricates full name 'Matija'.

examples.nl: papers by Mittal, Stanimirovic, and Babler on interstellar medium

issues.description: Invalid author field syntax: author:("^Mittal" "Stanimirovic" "Babler") is missing boolean operators between terms; this is not valid ADS query syntax.
issues.suggested_fix: author:("^Mittal" OR "Stanimirovic" OR "Babler") doctype:article abs:("interstellar medium")

issues.description: Natural language requests papers 'on interstellar medium' but the query only constrains authors and doctype; topic constraint is missing.
issues.suggested_fix: author:("^Mittal" OR "Stanimirovic" OR "Babler") abs:(interstellar AND medium) doctype:article

issues.description: Category is first_author, but only Mittal is marked as first author (^). NL does not specify first author, and if it did, it should apply consistently or be clarified.
issues.suggested_fix: author:("Mittal" OR "Stanimirovic" OR "Babler") abs:(interstellar AND medium) doctype:article

issues.description: Category 'first_author' does not match the NL intent (no explicit first-author request) and the query behavior (only one author is first-author constrained).

examples.nl: papers by de Zeeuw P T from 1999
examples.query: author:"^de Zeeuw P. T" year:1999 doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language specifies last name plus initials ("de Zeeuw P T"), but the query uses a different/extra initial formatting ("P. T"), which is not a literal translation and risks teaching the model to alter author initials.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"^de Zeeuw, P T" year:1999 doctype:article

issues.description: First-author constraint is applied (^) but the NL does not explicitly say "first author"; it only says "papers by". This adds an unrequested constraint.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"de Zeeuw, P T" year:1999 doctype:article

issues.description: Author string formatting is nonstandard/ambiguous (missing comma and unmatched quote placement around ^). Prefer canonical ADS author format with comma and ^ outside or inside consistently.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"^de Zeeuw, P T" year:1999 doctype:article

issues.description: Category is "first_author" but NL does not request first author; category should reflect a standard author+year query.

examples.nl: nautical charts South Australia coast Cape Du Couedic Whidbey Isles
examples.query: title:(Chart OR Aus343: OR Australia OR South OR Coast)

issues.description: Uses OR between mostly non-synonymous terms, making the query overly permissive and not aligned with the specific place-focused NL input.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("South Australia" AND coast AND chart AND ("Cape Du Couedic" OR "Whidbey Isles"))

issues.description: Query omits key NL entities ("Cape Du Couedic", "Whidbey Isles") and adds an unexplained token ("Aus343:") not present in the NL input.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("South Australia" AND coast AND chart AND ("Cape Du Couedic" OR "Whidbey Isles"))

issues.description: Invalid token in boolean list: "Aus343:" includes a trailing colon inside the term list, which is not a valid fielded clause and is likely a malformed field prefix/term.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(chart AND (Australia OR "South Australia") AND coast AND ("Cape Du Couedic" OR "Whidbey Isles"))

issues.description: Category 'content' is too generic; this is specifically a title/topic query.

examples.nl: papers by Sarkar K C since 2015

issues.description: Natural language specifies the full author name/initials "Sarkar K C" but the query only uses last name "Sarkar", which is less specific than requested.
Query uses a comma between clauses ("author:"^Sarkar", year:2015-"); ADS query syntax should not use commas as separators.
Year range is malformed: "year:2015-" is not a valid year range format. Use "year:2015-*" or a pubdate range.

examples.nl: papers by Carlson and Meixner from 2012

issues.description: Invalid author field syntax: author:("carlson" "Meixner") lacks a boolean operator between names; this is not valid ADS query syntax for combining multiple authors.
Natural language implies papers by both Carlson and Meixner; using OR returns papers by either author, not necessarily both.

examples.nl: History of Idaho; a narrative account of its historical progress, its people and its principal interests
examples.query: title:(History OR Idaho; OR narrative OR account OR its)

issues.description: Unescaped special character ';' is included as a token inside the title field, which can break parsing or produce unintended behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(History AND Idaho AND narrative AND account AND historical AND progress AND people AND interests)

issues.description: Uses OR between many non-synonymous terms, making the query far too permissive (matches papers with any single word). For topic/title-like inputs, terms should generally be combined with AND (or a quoted phrase if exact title is intended).
issues.suggested_fix: title:(History AND Idaho AND narrative AND account AND historical AND progress AND people AND interests)

issues.description: The natural language appears to be a full book title; the query truncates and drops key terms (e.g., 'historical progress', 'people', 'principal interests') and adds stopwords ('its').
issues.suggested_fix: title:"History of Idaho; a narrative account of its historical progress, its people and its principal interests"

issues.description: Category 'content' is too vague; this is specifically a title search example.
Natural language input is a bibcode; this is a direct identifier lookup rather than NL-to-query translation and should be removed from training data.
Query uses identifier:"..." instead of the more specific bibcode: field for a bibcode string, but this is moot since bibcode lookups should be removed.

examples.nl: windows XP service pack 2 springboard longhorn microsoft operating system
examples.query: title:(Windows OR SP2 OR 'Springboard' OR Longhorn)

issues.description: Uses single quotes around Springboard inside a fielded query; ADS query syntax requires double quotes for phrases and does not support single-quoted strings.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Windows OR SP2 OR "Springboard" OR Longhorn)

issues.description: Uses OR between multiple topic terms, making the query overly permissive (matches any one term) rather than requiring the combined topic implied by the NL input.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Windows AND (XP OR "service pack 2" OR SP2) AND (Springboard OR Longhorn) AND Microsoft AND "operating system")

issues.description: NL includes 'XP', 'service pack 2', 'microsoft', and 'operating system' but the query omits XP, Microsoft, and operating system, and reduces 'service pack 2' to SP2 only.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Windows AND XP AND ("service pack 2" OR SP2) AND (Springboard OR Longhorn) AND Microsoft AND "operating system")

examples.query: author:("Khaymovich, Ivan M" OR "Khaimovich, Ivan M") doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language only specifies last name "Khaymovich", but the query fabricates full given name and middle initial ("Ivan M").
Natural language includes topic constraint "on localization" but the query only filters by author and doctype, omitting the topic.
Query uses '^sunyaev' without a valid field prefix; '^' first-author operator must be applied to author: (e.g., ^author:"Name").
NL says 'papers by sunyaev' (author constraint) but query does not explicitly use author: field; also '^' implies first author, which was not requested.

examples.nl: NGC 3690 papers citing "A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies"
examples.query: abs: NGC 3690 citations(title:A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies) doctype:article

issues.description: Second-order operator syntax is invalid: citations() must wrap the entire inner query, not appear as a standalone token after abs:.
issues.suggested_fix: citations(title:"A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies") abs:"NGC 3690" doctype:article

issues.description: Invalid field clause formatting: `abs: NGC 3690` contains a space after the colon and a multi-word value without quotes/parentheses.
issues.suggested_fix: citations(title:"A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies") abs:"NGC 3690" doctype:article

issues.description: The cited work appears to be an exact paper title but is placed in title: without quotes, which can break parsing and teaches inconsistent title handling.
issues.suggested_fix: citations(title:"A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies") abs:"NGC 3690" doctype:article

issues.description: NL requests papers about object NGC 3690 that cite a specific paper; using abs: for the object is acceptable but object: would better match intent if treating NGC 3690 as an astronomical object name.
issues.suggested_fix: citations(title:"A Digital Archive of H I 21 Centimeter Line Spectra of Optically Targeted Galaxies") object:"NGC 3690" doctype:article

examples.nl: papers by szalai and shahbandeh on supernovae

issues.description: Natural language input only provides last name "szalai" but query fabricates an initial ("szalai, t").
Natural language requests papers by the authors "on supernovae" but the query omits the supernovae topic constraint.
Invalid field syntax: `title"1820"` is missing the required colon after the field name (`title:`).
Year constraint is incorrectly expressed as a title search for "1820" instead of using `year:` as implied by 'from 1820'.
Query uses first-author restriction (`^espinasse`) but NL only says 'papers by espinasse' (not explicitly first author).
Author field is malformed and does not correctly represent last-name-only author search for 'Barklem'.
Invalid author clause syntax: author:("Barklem.,") includes stray punctuation and unnecessary parentheses/quotes that likely break intended matching.
First-author syntax is incorrect: author:("^libanore") uses parentheses and quotes around a caret-prefixed token; ADS first-author should be expressed as ^author:"Name" or author:"^Name".

examples.nl: "Парад ансамблей" Владимир Заседателев ВИА Лейся musical ensemble
examples.query: title:(Парад OR ансамблей OR музыкант: OR Владимир OR Заседателев)

issues.description: Unbalanced parentheses: query has an opening '(' after title: but no matching closing ')'.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Парад AND ансамблей AND Владимир AND Заседателев)

issues.description: Uses an invalid field token inside the title clause: "музыкант:" is not a valid ADS field and the trailing colon makes it malformed as a term.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Парад AND ансамблей AND Владимир AND Заседателев AND музыкант)

issues.description: Uses OR between multiple non-synonymous terms, making the query overly permissive for a specific phrase/name search.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Парад AND ансамблей AND Владимир AND Заседателев)

issues.description: Natural language includes additional constraints (e.g., "ВИА Лейся" / musical ensemble) that are omitted from the query.
issues.suggested_fix: title:(Парад AND ансамблей AND Владимир AND Заседателев AND ВИА AND Лейся)

examples.nl: "An Introduction to Geography, Intended for Little Children" third edition
examples.query: title:(Introduction OR Geography, OR Intended OR Little OR Children,)3rd ed.""

issues.description: Query has unbalanced quotes and malformed structure (e.g., trailing '3rd ed.""' and mismatched parentheses/quotes).
issues.suggested_fix: title:("An Introduction to Geography" AND "Intended for Little Children")

issues.description: Uses OR between many non-synonymous title words, making the query far too permissive and not aligned with an exact title request.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("An Introduction to Geography" AND "Intended for Little Children")

issues.description: Natural language requests a specific work and edition ('third edition'), but the query does not represent edition information in a valid/meaningful way and includes stray punctuation tokens (commas).
issues.suggested_fix: title:("An Introduction to Geography" AND "Intended for Little Children" AND ("third edition" OR "3rd edition"))

issues.description: Natural language only specifies last name "coutu"; query fabricates initial "s".
First-author constraint is expressed, but uses a nonstandard pattern with an added initial; better to use ^ with last name only.

examples.query: pubdate:[2013-01 TO 2013-12] author:("Piskunov, a. e.") doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language only specifies last name "Piskunov", but query fabricates initials and lowercases them: author:("Piskunov, a. e.").
Author clause uses parentheses and quotes in a nonstandard way for a single author name: author:("..."). Prefer author:"...".
Query uses a comma between clauses; ADS query syntax requires boolean operators or whitespace, not commas.
First-author marker is applied to alfaro, but the NL input does not explicitly request first author.

examples.nl: papers about stellar evolution in binary systems

issues.description: Query uses invalid/unknown field/operator `docs(...)` inside abs:. `docs` is not part of valid ADS query syntax.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(stellar evolution AND binary systems) doctype:article

issues.description: Query does not reflect the natural-language topic; it appears to use an opaque token/hash rather than topic terms about stellar evolution and binary systems.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(stellar evolution AND binary systems) doctype:article

examples.nl: papers about Jack London's Call of the Wild in literary criticism
examples.query: title:(Jack OR London's OR 'The OR Call OR Wild') doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language request is about literary criticism of a fiction work (not an ADS/SciX-appropriate scholarly astronomy/physics topic); query attempts to force-match a non-scholarly title-like string and will not teach correct ADS topic translation.
Title clause uses OR between individual words (and even broken tokens like "London's" and "'The"), making the query far too permissive and not representative of the intended concept.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("Call of the Wild" AND London) doctype:article

issues.description: Unbalanced/invalid quoting in title clause ("London's" and "'The" introduce problematic apostrophes/quotes that are not valid ADS quoting syntax as written).
issues.suggested_fix: title:("Call of the Wild" AND London) doctype:article

issues.description: Category 'content' is too vague; this is primarily a title/topic query example (and also out-of-domain for ADS).
Unquoted multi-word object name in abs: clause: abs:(HD 110058) will be parsed as separate tokens without explicit boolean/phrase handling.
Natural language asks for 'stellar properties' but the query only includes the object name and omits the topic constraint.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:("HD 110058" AND (stellar OR star) AND (property OR properties)) doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language is a topic query about combustion flame extinction limits/flammability, but the generated query is a DOI/identifier lookup, which does not translate the topic.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(combustion AND flame AND extinction AND (flammability OR flammability-limits)) doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language only specifies last name 'Ladjelate' but query fabricates initial 'B.' in author field.
First-author syntax is nonstandard/incorrect: author:("^Ladjelate, B.") uses parentheses and includes fabricated initials; should use ^author:"Ladjelate" or author:"^Ladjelate".

examples.nl: machine learning applications in stellar classification 2023

issues.description: Query uses invalid field/operator '+docs(...)' which is not part of ADS/SciX query syntax.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(machine learning AND stellar classification) year:2023

issues.description: Query does not represent the natural language topic (machine learning applications in stellar classification); it instead references an internal docs/library identifier.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(machine learning AND stellar classification) year:2023

issues.description: Category 'publication' is not descriptive of the query intent; this is a topic + year constraint.

examples.nl: papers by j.v. rodriguez from 2017 to 2023 mentioning 2017

issues.description: NL specifies author as "j.v. rodriguez" (initials before last name), but query uses author:"j.v. rodriguez" which is not a valid/robust ADS author format and risks teaching incorrect author formatting. ADS expects "Last" or "Last, F" / "Last, First".
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Rodriguez, J V" year:2017-2023 abs:2017 doctype:article

issues.description: The term 2017 is quoted in abs:"2017" though it is a single token and does not require quotes.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Rodriguez, J V" year:2017-2023 abs:2017 doctype:article

examples.nl: "BY THE GREAT HORN SPOON" Kirkus Reviews
examples.query: title:(GREAT OR HORN OR SPOON! OR Kirkus OR Reviews)

issues.description: Query uses OR between all title terms, making it far too permissive and likely to match unrelated records containing any single word (e.g., just 'Great' or 'Reviews').
issues.suggested_fix: title:("BY THE GREAT HORN SPOON" AND "Kirkus Reviews")

issues.description: Invalid character '!' included in a token (SPOON!) which can cause parsing issues; punctuation should be removed or the phrase should be quoted as-is without stray punctuation tokens.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("BY THE GREAT HORN SPOON" AND "Kirkus Reviews")

issues.description: Natural language appears to reference a specific titled work and source ('Kirkus Reviews'); the query should target the exact title phrase rather than splitting into individual words.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("BY THE GREAT HORN SPOON" AND "Kirkus Reviews")

issues.description: Category 'content' is too vague; this is specifically a title search example.

examples.nl: papers about Wyatt Earp frontier lawman
examples.query: title:(Who OR Wyatt OR Earp?) doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language topic (Wyatt Earp frontier lawman) is not an astronomy/physics scholarly topic appropriate for ADS/SciX; query terms are unrelated and appear to be guessing at a specific title ('Who') and adding a wildcard ('Earp?') without NL support.
title:(Who OR Wyatt OR Earp?) is overly permissive and likely to retrieve irrelevant results; for a topic it should use abs: with AND between required concepts rather than OR across unrelated tokens.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:(Wyatt AND Earp AND frontier AND lawman) doctype:article

issues.description: Category 'content' is too vague; should be 'topic' (or similar) if kept.

examples.nl: He-who-sees-in-the-dark Boys Story Frederick Burnham American Scout
examples.query: title:(He-who-sees-in-the-dark; OR Boys' OR Story OR Frederick OR Burnham,)

issues.description: Malformed title field grouping: contains punctuation tokens (';', ',', "Boys'") and an OR placed inside parentheses in a way that is not valid ADS query syntax; also includes a trailing comma inside the field group.
issues.suggested_fix: title:("He-who-sees-in-the-dark" AND Boys AND Story AND Frederick AND Burnham AND "American Scout")

issues.description: Uses OR between many non-synonymous terms, making the query far too permissive and not aligned with an intended specific work/topic.
Natural language looks like a specific title/entity query; generated query breaks it into many loose OR terms, likely returning unrelated results.
Category 'content' is too vague; this is primarily a title/known-item lookup style query.

examples.nl: X-ray binary luminosity functions M81 spiral galaxy globular clusters
examples.query: abs:(Calibrating AND X-ray AND XLF AND X-ray)

issues.description: Query does not reflect the natural language topics (X-ray binary luminosity functions, M81, spiral galaxy, globular clusters). It instead includes unrelated term 'Calibrating' and duplicates 'X-ray', and omits key constraints like M81 and globular clusters.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:("X-ray binary" AND ("luminosity function" OR XLF) AND M81 AND "globular cluster*")

issues.description: Redundant term 'X-ray' appears twice and the query structure does not include the required topic components from NL.
issues.suggested_fix: abs:("X-ray binary" AND ("luminosity function" OR XLF) AND M81 AND "globular cluster*")

examples.nl: exclude STAR acronym but include star

issues.description: Invalid use of '=' inside a fielded term: title:(=star -STAR). ADS query syntax does not support '=star' as a term; '=' is only valid as a prefix to the author field for exact matching (e.g., =author:"...").

Natural language requests excluding the STAR acronym but including the word 'star' generally implies case-sensitive exclusion or acronym handling; ADS queries are typically case-insensitive, so '-STAR' may also exclude 'star' depending on indexing behavior. The query may not reliably satisfy the intent.

examples.nl: papers by vera rubin on dark energy since 2018
examples.query: author:"rubin, v" abs:"dark energy" year:2018-2023 doctype:article

issues.description: Natural language says 'vera rubin' (full name), but query uses only an initial (author:"rubin, v"), which is a lossy/possibly incorrect transformation for training data.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Rubin, Vera" abs:(dark AND energy) year:2018-2023 doctype:article

issues.description: Topic phrase is quoted in abs:"dark energy" even though this is a general topic; training should prefer boolean topic terms unless an exact phrase is explicitly requested.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Rubin, Vera" abs:(dark AND energy) year:2018-2023 doctype:article

issues.description: NL says 'since 2018' (open-ended), but query constrains to year:2018-2023, adding an upper bound not stated by the user.
issues.suggested_fix: author:"Rubin, Vera" abs:(dark AND energy) year:2018-* doctype:article

issues.description: NL input provides only the last name "rubin" but the query fabricates an initial ("v").
The topic phrase "infrared astronomy" is quoted without the NL explicitly requesting an exact phrase; topic terms should typically be combined with AND.

NL looks like a topic query (vera rubin + infrared astronomy). The query mixes an author constraint with a quoted phrase; better to treat the topic as keywords with boolean logic and avoid fabricated author details.

Natural language only specifies last name 'oort' and initial 'j' separately; the query fabricates a formatted author string with an initial that may not be explicitly intended as an author initial in ADS format.
The topic phrase "weak lensing" is quoted even though the NL does not explicitly request an exact phrase; topic terms should generally be combined with boolean operators.
Topic terms are not expressed with boolean logic; using AND between topic keywords is preferred for topic searches.

Natural language input only provides last name/initials as 'oort j' (not an explicit author format like 'J. Oort' or 'Jan Oort'), but query fabricates a specific author string with last name and initial ordering: author:"oort, j".
Topic phrase is quoted as an exact phrase in abs:, even though the input does not explicitly request an exact phrase search.
Input looks like keywords rather than an explicit author constraint; treating 'oort j' as an author may be incorrect without clearer NL intent (e.g., 'papers by Oort').
Natural language specifies only last name 'huchra' but query fabricates an initial ('j').
NL says 'not 2mass' without specifying field; query restricts exclusion to title only, which may under-exclude compared to user intent.
